title: pound sterling dollar exchange rates brexit deal michel barnier
story: Created with Sketch.The EU's chief negotiator said the bloc is ready for a no-deal BrexitClick to followThe IndependentMr Barnier back-tracked somewhat on optimistic remarks from WednesdayThe pound&nbspdropped against the dollar on Wednesday, falling back from gains made off the back of optimist Brexit outlooks offered by both EU and British negotiators on Tuesday. Sterling fell by as much as 0.3 per cent against the dollar&nbspafter the EU’s chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, said in a German radio interview that the bloc is prepared for a no-deal Brexit. “After the sterling bounce yesterday,&nbspBarnier has used a German radio interview this morning to remind the market that the EU is also planning for a no-deal scenario,” Jeremy Stretch at Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, told Bloomberg.“This suggests they are not intent on a deal at all costs and that sterling gains may prove tough to hold onto.”The pound was boosted on Tuesday, rising 1.2 per cent against the dollar, and 1 per cent against the euro, after Mr Barnier said the EU is “prepared to offer a partnership with Britain such as has never been with any other third country. His positive remarks came as Brexit secretary Dominic Raab told the Lords EU committee that he was “confident a deal is within our sights”“We're bringing ambition, pragmatism, energy and if, and I expect it will be, and if it is matched, we get a deal,” he said. Hussein Sayed, chief market strategist at FXTM, said many investors would be wondering whether Mr Barnier’s positive statement on Wednesday could be a turning point for the pound. “Although many issues related to trade and the Irish border are far from being resolved, it currently seems that negotiations may begin moving in the right direction. However, expect volatility to surge in the coming weeks as we get closer to the Brexit deadline,” he said.The pound remained up against the euro, trading up 0.02 per cent at €1.1128 by mid-morning.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

title: jurassic fossil rat egg laying arizona discovered reptiles mammals evolution
story: Created with Sketch.Discovery of trilodont with 38 hatched and unhatched offspring indicates&nbspcritical step in the evolution of mammals was trading big litters for big brains, study saysClick to followThe IndependentA figure representing the 38 Kayentatherium babies found with an adult specimen. They are the only known fossils of babies from an extinct mammal relative that lived during the early Jurassic periodA “rarest of the rare” fossil of an enormous fanged rat-like animal surrounded by a litter of 38 hatched and unhatched offspring has been unearthed in Arizona, offering new insight into the transition between reptiles and mammals during the Jurassic period.Mammals are today distinguished by their means of reproduction in which they produce relatively few, live young. In comparison, reptiles lay large clutches of eggs. The discovery of a baby snake fossil offers a clue on their evolutionDinosaurs are much weirder than we ever thoughtHow did birds survive the dinosaur-killing asteroid?Birds ‘had to learn to fly again’ after meteor killed dinosaursThe creature, named Kayentatherium wellesi, and which was a forerunner to modern mammals and belonged to a group known as the tritylodonts, was about the size of a small dog, and had large fangs on both its upper and lower jaw. &nbspDespite its appearance, it was herbivorous, and would have lived alongside dinosaurs about 185 million years ago.The remarkable discovery of the animal’s offspring comes a full 18 years after the initial mother’s remains were found, when palaeontologists re-examined the sediment sample and carried out CT scans to reveal the huge litter. “Looking at the CT scans I was able to discover baby after baby after baby,” said study leader Eva Hoffman, who led the research as a graduate student in geosciences at the University of Texas at Austin.“These babies are from a really important point in the evolutionary tree,” she added. “They had a lot of features similar to modern mammals, features that are relevant in understanding mammalian evolution.”Kayentatherium. It is about 1 centimetre long (Eva Hoffman  The University of Texas at Austin)Zhe-Xi Luo, a palaeontologist and professor at The University of Chicago, described the discovery as “stunning” and said&nbspthey would&nbspprovide scientists valuable insight into mammal evolution.“These great fossils really gave us a rare glimpse of how early mammals evolved from their ancestors,” he said.The highly detailed scans allowed Ms Hoffman to examine the shape of the offsprings’ skulls, which appear as “scaled down replicas” a tenth of the size of the adult and with all features in proportion - a trait typically seen in reptile offspring. In modern mammals, young are born with shortened faces and bulbous heads to account for big brains.The discovery that Kayentatherium had a tiny brain and many babies, despite otherwise having much in common with mammals, suggests a critical step in the evolution of mammals was trading big litters for big brains, and that this step happened later in mammalian evolution, the study said.Ms Hoffman co-authored the study with her graduate adviser, Jackson School Professor Timothy Rowe, who unearthed the fossil in 2000. Sebastian Egberts, a former graduate student and fossil preparator at the Jackson School, spotted the first sign of the babies years later when a grain-sized speck of tooth enamel caught his eye in 2009 as he was unpacking the fossil.“It didn’t look like a pointy fish tooth or a small tooth from a primitive reptile,” said Mr Egberts, who is now an instructor of anatomy at the Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine. “It looked more like a molariform tooth (molar-like tooth) — and that got me very excited.”Kayentatherium was a forerunner to modern mammals (Eva Hoffman  The University of Texas at Austin)A CT scan of the fossil undertaken in 2009 revealed a handful of bones inside the rock. But it took advances in CT-imaging technology during the next seven years, the expertise of technicians at UT Austin’s High-Resolution X-ray Computed Tomography Facility (UTCT), and extensive digital processing by Ms Hoffman to reveal the rest of the offspring - not just their jaws and teeth, but complete skulls and partial skeletons - the University of Texas said in a statement.Dinosaurs in the Wild Dinosaurs in the WildDinosaurs in the WildPair of QuetzalcoatlusDinosaurs in the WildDinosaurs in the WildDinosaurs in the WildDinosaurs in the WildChronotex X90 with an AlamosaurusDinosaurs in the WildTyrannosaurus and geyserDinosaurs in the WildDinosaurs in the WildTimebase 67 and a QuetzalcoatlusDinosaurs in the Wildriceratops with a Chronotex X90Dinosaurs in the WildDinosarus in the WildDinosaurs in the WildDinosaurs in the WildPair of QuetzalcoatlusDinosaurs in the WildDinosaurs in the WildDinosaurs in the WildDinosaurs in the WildChronotex X90 with an AlamosaurusDinosaurs in the WildTyrannosaurus and geyserDinosaurs in the WildDinosaurs in the WildTimebase 67 and a QuetzalcoatlusDinosaurs in the Wildriceratops with a Chronotex X90Dinosaurs in the WildDinosarus in the Wild“There are additional deep stories on the evolution of development, and the evolution of mammalian intelligence and behaviour and physiology that can be squeezed out of a remarkable fossil like this now that we have the technology to study it,” Professor Rowe said.To find so many offspring together from the Jurassic period is unprecedented as young animals would tend to have been destroyed or eaten in the event they had not made it to adulthood.University of TexasEnter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

story: Created with Sketch.Temperatures set to climb to 25C&nbspas September begins with blue skies and dry conditionsClick to followThe IndependentUK weather: Summer set for last hurrah as heat and sunshine return this weekendJust as Britain was begrudgingly&nbspaccepting it had waved goodbye to summer, the hot weather is to return for one final flourish.Temperatures are forecast to soar to an unseasonably warm 25C&nbspthis weekend as September kicks off with blue skies and dry conditions.It comes after a summer of extreme heat gave way to a changeable August, culminating&nbspin a Bank Holiday washout across much of the country last Sunday.The Met Office said most of the UK would see warm sunshine return at the weekend, with the south coast of England expected to get the best of the weather.Senior forecaster Marco&nbspPetagna said: Saturday, Sunday and Monday are looking like a bit of a return to warmer days.Between now and then things will be around about average for this time of year - high teens to early&nbsp20s.But as we get into the weekend and early next week we can expect highs of&nbsp23C and&nbsp24C on Saturday in the southeast of England, maybe&nbsp25C&nbspon Sunday, and maybe even slightly higher on the Monday.He said the warm&nbspweather&nbspwould be caused by high pressure and a slight wind bringing temperatures from continental Europe with it.UK news in picturesShelves of energy drinks on sale. story: Created with Sketch.Customers told they are still required to repay any outstanding money despite collapseClick to followThe IndependentControversial firm stopped accepting applications for loans hours before collapsingWonga has collapsed into administration.The controversial payday lender’s collapse puts 500 jobs at risk and comes hours after it&nbspstopped accepting applications for loans.In a statement, Wonga&nbspsaid that having addressed all options, the board “concluded that it is appropriate to place the businesses into administration”.It added: “Wonga customers can continue to use Wonga services to manage their existing loans but the UK business will not be accepting any new loan applications. Customers can find further information on the website.”Corporate undertakers at Grant Thornton have been appointed to carry out the administration and it is expected the company will now run Wonga’s loan book.Customers were being told by the company that despite the collapse, they are still required to repay any outstanding money.Over the weekend, Wonga said it was “considering all options”, just weeks after shareholders pumped £10 million in a bid to save it from going bust.Investors in Wonga include Balderton Capital, Accel Partners, Greylock Partners and 83North.Business news: in picturesIconic British car maker Jaguar Land Rover warned on July 5, 2018 that a bad Brexit deal could jeopardise planned investment of more than $100 billion, upping corporate pressure as the government heads into crucial talks.Spotify traded publically for the first time on the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday. Flybe said it cancelled 994 flights in the three months to 31 March, compared to 372 in the same period last year.Earlier this month, the lender said its struggles were due to a “significant” industry-wide increase in people making claims in relation to historic loans.It blamed claims management companies for the rise, but said it was making progress against a transformation plan set out for the business.On Sunday, Wonga said the number of complaints related to UK loans taken out before 2014 had “accelerated further”.“Against this claims backdrop, the Wonga board continues to assess all options regarding the future of the group and all of its entities,” the company said at the time.Wonga&nbsphas been harshly criticised for the high interest it charges on its loans and has been accused of targeting those who are vulnerable.In 2014, the firm introduced a new management team and wrote off £220 million of debt belonging to 330,000 customers after admitting making loans to people who could not afford to repay them.In the same year, the Financial Conduct Authority said it would bring in stricter affordability checks to the industry and introduce a cap on the cost of payday loans on the amount borrowed per day.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

title: chelsea manning australia ban visa character test tour new zealand
story: Created with Sketch.‘Substantial criminal record’&nbspmakes&nbspher ineligible for visa, government saysClick to followThe IndependentThe American whistleblower has speaking engagements planned in the countryChelsea Manning has been barred from visiting Australia for a speaking tour after failing a character test, her event organiser has said.Ms Manning, who served seven years of a 35-year sentence for passing classified information to WikiLeaks, had been due at the first of a series of public talks on Sunday.But event organiser Think Inc said it had received a notice of intention from Canberra&nbspto deny Ms Manning entry.In the letter, obtained by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the whistleblower was told her “substantial criminal record”&nbspmade her ineligible for entry.Australia’s Department of Home Affairs refused to comment on her case but said all non-citizens entering Australia must meet character requirements set out in the Migration Act.The reasons a person might fail the character test include a criminal record or a determination they might pose a danger to the community.Protesters urge Obama to commute Chelsea Manning's sentencePeople hold signs calling for the release of imprisoned wikileaks whistleblower Chelsea Manning while marching in a gay pride parade in San Francisco, California June 28, 2015. story: Created with Sketch.Researchers found automated accounts were 40 per cent more likely than genuine accounts to support right-wing Sweden DemocratsStaff and agenciesClick to followThe IndependentJimmie Akesson, leader of the Sweden Democrats, on the campaign trailSurge in fake Twitter accounts spouting anti-immigrant bile sparks fears of outside interference in Swedish electionA recent surge in Twitter bots promoting anti-immigrant views in Sweden has sparked fears malign outside forces may be trying to influence the country's forthcoming election.&nbspA study by&nbspSweden's defence research agency&nbspdiscovered a sudden sharp rise in the number of automated Twitter accounts – with some&nbsp40 per cent of them favouring&nbspthe anti-immigration Sweden Democrats party, which is expected to make gains in the poll on September 9.It indicated&nbspthe number of Twitter bots discussing politics nearly doubled from July to August, adding&nbspusers may be led to believe that this content (is) more widely accepted or more mainstream than it actually is.The FOI&nbspagency, which analysed almost 600,000 tweets from more than 45,000 accounts, did not say who might be behind the fake accounts.Hopefully, this study will contribute to a greater awareness of possible effects of the bots, so more citizens make their decisions without being affected by them, researcher Johan&nbspFernquist said.Last year, Sweden's domestic intelligence agency briefed politicians about the potential risk of foreign inference in the vote to renew the 349-seat Riksdagen.At the time, prime minister Stefan Lofven told Swedish broadcaster SVT that it has become increasingly obvious that foreign powers are trying to influence an election and its outcome. He added that obviously Russia was active in the US elections and we cannot assume that we are immune.Four US intelligence agencies have concluded Moscow sought to influence the outcome of the race for the White House.&nbspSwedish crown jewels stolen by pair of thieves who fled scene by boatSweden calls for international help as wildfires rage in Arctic circleThousands of Swedes are inserting themselves with microchipsSwedish Muslim woman wins case after refusing to shake hands with manStudent who stopped deportation of asylum seeker could face prisonPresident Trump, after infamously failing to hold Vladimir Putin to account on the issue during a face-to-face meeting, subsequently said he holds his Russian counterpart personally responsible for the alleged efforts to interfere in the 2016 US election.Polls suggest the Sweden Democrats - currently the country's third-largest political group, but considered a pariah in Swedish politics - could eclipse&nbspthe main opposition, the liberal Moderates, to become the country's second-largest party.Sweden's largest party, the ruling Social Democrats, built the country's famed welfare state.The Sweden Democrats, born out of a radical nationalist movement with neo-Nazi links, has softened its rhetoric and expelled openly racist members. title: Kruger National Park lions trap tourists biting tyres south africa
story: Lions have been attacking vehicles north of Satara in the Kruger National Park (Image: NC)Now KNP management have put out an urgent warning to visitors to be on the guard for the pride to avoid being left feline flat if the lions try to use their tyres to gnaw on.KNP want to find the pride responsible so they can collar one of the lions to monitors its movements and behaviour and to mark the whole pride for easy identification.KNP Managing Executive Glenn Phillips said: &ldquoWe urge visitors who come across this pride to keep their windows closed and those in open safari vehicles to stay silent and keep all limbs within the vehicle structure.&ldquoWe would like to appeal to the open safari vehicle operators specifically to be on the lookout as the behaviour of the pride is of concern and might pose danger to occupants.                Ten things you never knew about... lions                 World Lion Day: Stars appeal for ex-circus lion sanctuary&ldquoVeterinary Wildlife Services will be collaring one of the lions when the pride is found to monitor its movements and will also mark all members of the pride to allow for identification.The park boss warns drivers who suffer punctures not to get out and change the tyre but to call park administrators who will send out a ranger and a breakdown service to help.The park is also asking for visitors who have come across this pride to share any videos or photos they may have taken of a lion puncturing tyres to the park's social media platforms.Mr Phillips said: &ldquoThis will help identify whether it is only a specific member of the pride engaging in the unusual behaviour or whether the entire pride of lions is involved.A lion ready to attack another car  (Image: NC)Dashcam footage of a Lion in action  (Image: NC)Last October the rare occurrence of a lion biting a tyre was captured in the Kruger by British teenager Sean Obeirne who was on holiday with his family at the Tshokwane camp.He posted his video on KNP&rsquos You Tube channel LatestSightings.Com.Sean, 13, said: &ldquoWe watched as a young male lion approached a car and my younger brother and I were laughing and joking that the lion may scratch the paint or damage the vehicle.&ldquoIn the midst of our jokes there was an almighty bang and the lion investigating the car ran off in fright and once we realised it had punctured the tyre our laughing just tripled he said.Sean&rsquos father organised his car and others to surround the stricken car with a burst tyre and bravely got out and jacked it up and changed the tyre to get the family with the flat moving again.The young lion can be seen here sniffing the tyre then chomping into the tread then leaping backwards and up into the air in fright as the tyre explodes with a hiss and bang right in his face.

story: Royal Collection Trust of archaeologist Alan Radley with the items found at the Palace (Image: PA)Items discovered during excavation work in Edinburgh this year include a 12th-century jug fragment, a horse skeleton and a medieval shoe.The diets of ambassadors and courtiers at Abbey Strand - during the reigns of Mary, Queen of Scots and James VI - were also revealed by the mass of oyster shells and wine bottles dug up.Researchers also say wine and spirit containers, food debris and fragments of children's games give a glimpse of life for the 25 impoverished families living in cramped tenements in the area during the 18th and 19th centuries.Gordon Ewart of Kirkdale Archaeology, which carried out the work, said: The survey has provided a unique opportunity to understand more about the fascinating development of the Abbey Strand and its surroundings - and to explore how the site has been the historic and symbolic bridge between the palace and the city of Edinburgh for centuries.                Theresa May uses THIS Queen Elizabeth anecdote to WOO Kenya into deal                Meghan Markle broke royal protocol and the Queen&rsquos &lsquoonly rule&rsquoMore than 40 trenches were dug for an archaeological survey as part of the &pound10 million works to improve the visitor experience at the palace.Excavations in the Abbey Strand buildings by the Edinburgh-based firm uncovered the earliest evidence of settlement on the site.Timber posts dating from the 12th century are believed to mark the location of a terrace that led to the then low-lying island on which Holyrood Abbey was built in 1128.They could also have formed part of a structure used by the workmen who built the Abbey.Items include a 12th-century jug fragment, a horse skeleton and a medieval shoe (Image: PA)Queen Elizabeth II (C) meets guests as she hosts the annual garden party at Holyroodhouse (Image: )One of the earliest finds is a medieval leather shoe from beneath one of the cellars in the Abbey Strand.The bones of Highland cattle found in the gardens provide evidence of trading between Edinburgh and the Highlands and Western Isles.The palace is used by the Queen when carrying out official engagements in Scotland.

title: cold weather forecast big freeze solar minimum maximum space news
story: Scientists are reporting that the sun has been free of sunspots for a total of 133 days this year.With only 241 days of 2018 passing, that means the sun has been blank for the majority of the year.Experts warn this is a sign that the solar minimum is on its way.Website Space Weather says: &ldquoThe sun is spotless again. For the 133rd day this year, the face of the sun is blank.                Solar storm threat: Earth at risk after coronal HOLE forms in Sun                THIS is how historic spacecraft will withstand sun&rsquos heat &ldquoTo find a year with fewer sunspots, you have to go back to 2009 when the sun was experiencing the deepest solar minimum in a century.&ldquoSolar minimum has returned, bringing extra cosmic rays, long-lasting holes in the sun's atmosphere, and strangely pink auroras.The sun follows cycles of roughly 11 years where it reaches a solar maximum and then a solar minimum.During a solar maximum, the sun gives off more heat and is littered with sunspots. Less heat in a solar minimum is due to a decrease in magnetic waves.The sun was not expected to head into a solar minimum until around 2020, but it appears to be heading in early which could prove to be bad news.Cold weather forecast: Sun goes BLANK for majority of the year - Earth set for big freeze (Image: )The last time there was a prolonged solar minimum, it led to a &lsquomini ice-age&rsquo, scientifically known as the Maunder minimum - which lasted for 70 years.The Maunder minimum, which saw seven decades of freezing weather, began in 1645 and lasted through to 1715, and happened when sunspots were exceedingly rare.During this period, temperatures dropped globally by 1.3 degrees Celsius leading to shorter seasons and ultimately food shortages.The blank sun (Image: SDO &bull HMI)Vencore Weather, a meteorological website, said: &ldquoLow solar activity is known to have consequences on Earth&rsquos weather and climate and it also is well correlated with an increase in cosmic rays that reach the upper part of the atmosphere.&ldquoThe blank sun is a sign that the next solar minimum is approaching and there will be an increasing number of spotless days over the next few years.

story: Lord Adonis blasted the leading Brexiteer after a 2016 video emerged of Jacob Rees-Mogg calling for Irish border controls as we had during the troubles.In a scathing attack of the Tory backbencher, Lord Adonis suggested supporters of Mr Rees-Mogg are extremists pressuring the Government into a hard Brexit.Speaking to BBC Foyle, the Labour peer said: Jacob Rees-Mogg speaks for about the 10 percent most extreme part of the Conservative Party, which is a tiny fraction of the House of Commons.The problem we&rsquove got is this 10 percent of extremists are the tail wagging the dog at the moment. They&rsquove got Theresa May in their grip, they keep threatening to call leadership elections.                'France must EXPEL the English!' French fishermen threaten UK Lord Adonis, who quit his Government post as head of National Infrastructure Commission to fight Brexit, branded as mind-boggling suggestions to reinstitute border patrols once Britain leaves the European Union.He continued: The idea that we should regard as a precedent for how we handle the big problem we&rsquod have about massive smuggling across the border, the idea that we regard as a precedent for those border guards in the Troubles is mind-boggling.What we&rsquove got is a policy of a Government which is being dictated by extremists. In Northern Ireland, you know only too well what it&rsquos like to have policy dictated by extremists.He added: You might think it&rsquos a joke and somehow reason will prevail and everything will be ok but I can assure that doesn&rsquot always happen. That&rsquos why I think Jacob Rees-Mogg is a very dangerous and threatening force.Brexit news: Lord Adonis said Mr Rees-Mogg is a  (Image: )Responding to Lord Adonis' comments, Mr Rees-Mogg told Express: It is a rather peculiar view, all I want is for the Brexit people voted for to take place.This is not an extreme view but One held by the bulk of the country according to opinion polls.It is a matter for pity that some remainers are so emotionally attached to the EU that they cannot reconcile themselves to the referendum result&rsquo.The 2016 video shows Mr Rees-Mogg advocating for inspections on people crossing the Irish border. While shared widely on social media over the past few days, it appears to have been recorded in the run-up to the Brexit referendum.Brexit news: Rees-Mogg said it was matter of pity for Remainers to be emotionally attached to EU (Image: )The Irish border, which zig-zags for more than 300 miles across the north-east of Ireland and is crossed by 200 public roads, has been the biggest issue facing Britain as it leaves the EU.During the Troubles, the period of civil unrest in Ireland during the late-20th century, major border crossings were blocked by British Army checkpoints, with some smaller routes closed completely.Fears of a return to a hard border and a return to bloodshed have grown since England and Wales voted to leave the EU in June 2016. Northern Ireland, like Scotland, voted heavily in favour of Remain.The British Government remains unable to explain how cross-border trade and the movement of goods will continue after Brexit without the establishment of customs checkpoints or even CCTV cameras - which would constitute a hard border, a red line issue for Dublin, Belfast and Brussels.

story: Stock-on-Trent MP Jack Brereton suggested that EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier is unlikely to agree to any deal that would see the creation of new tariff barriers with the UK after Brexit.Mr Brereton told Express in June that EU member states will not want unnecessary tariffs that could harm their trade.He said: We have still got some way to go and the next stage is particularly the economic and trade elements of that. I think we will come to a stage where we get an effective trade policy around that.We must also consider the fact that it&rsquos not just that the UK doesn&rsquot want to have unnecessary tariffs on trade. Those European countries will not want to have unnecessary and ineffective tariffs on trade because it will hit them just as much as they would hit us.                Brexit news: Farage warns don't fall for Barnier's 'FORKED tongue'Mr Brereton remained confident Britain and the bloc will be able to strike a new arrangement in the time left to negotiate which would also ensure no hard border is created in Northern Ireland.He continued: We do want to maintain those economic links with the European Union, have that frictionless trade and I think there are ways of achieving that.We don&rsquot want that hard border with Northern Ireland, but we don&rsquot want a hard border along the Irish Channel either.&nbspCertainly, we can do that and achieve that through means of technology, introducing more effective technology at borders.I think that would be a really good way to ensure that it isn&rsquot so burdensome of the measures that we introduce.Brexit news: Jack Brereton said EU countries do not want  (Image: EXPRESS.CO.UK&bull)Mr Barnier announced on Wednesday Brussels is prepared to offer London a deal like no other third country in an unexpected move after the start of the last phase of withdrawal talks.The Frenchman stressed the UK and EU are entering the final stages of the negotiations and have to be very careful because the last phase is very sensitive and difficult.He affirmed that Theresa May's commitment to an Irish backstop, insisting it must be part of any withdrawal agreement.Mr Barnier added: In addition to the agreement, we must publish in October or November a very important political declaration on the future relationship, that we want with the UK to be as close as possible.The EU's chief negotiator is set to meet Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab on Friday after reports that UK officials are growing frustrated at the lack of time the EU negotiator is affording them during the talks.

title: work emails commute journey out of hours research
story: Checking emails while commuting should be 'counted as work' (Image: getty)A study conducted by the University of West England found that commuters spend so much time working before and after hours that including travel time in the working day could be viable.&nbspResearchers found that 54 percent of respondents spent their journey working on a mobile phone.&nbspChiltern Railways increased the amount of free Wifi available to passengers on its mainline route over 40-weeks.&nbspOf the 3000 travellers who were surveyed, the number of commuters connecting to wifi rose from 54 per cent when 20mb of internet was available to 60 per cent when 125mb was offered.&nbsp                A sweet life for work-all-hours confectioner                How to commute with confidence on an eBikeIn contrast, the connection to mobile data fluctuated be around 48 percent.A total of 5000 passengers were surveyed travelling on two of Chiltern Railways&rsquo routes, between London and Birmingham, and London and Aylesbury.Commuters called this time valuable to &lsquocatch up&rsquo.Parents said it was a transitional period where they could prepare to switch from their role of getting children ready for school to business director during the day.&nbspSmartphones are blurring the lines between work and home life (Image: getty)Dr Juliet Jain, speaking at the Royal Geographical Society annual conference today, said: &ldquoIf travel time were to count as work time, there would be many social and economic impacts, as well as implications for the rail industry.&nbsp&ldquoIt may ease commuter pressure on peak hours and allow for more comfort and flexibility around working times. However it may also demand more surveillance and accountability for productivity.Smartphones and the potential for wider internet coverage during journeys is &ldquoblurring the boundaries between life at home and work.&nbspResearcher Dr Juliet Jain, from the University&rsquos Centre for Transport and society, told the BBC: &ldquoHow do we count that time? Do workplace cultures need to change?&nbsp                Are folding bikes any good? We put the Carrera Transit to the testIn Norway some commuters are able to count travel time as part of their working day.&nbspBut introducing this in the UK would require trains to provide a better working environment, including tables, power, space and seamless internet connection but this would require investment from train operators and telecom industries, the report said.&nbspReacting to the study, people took to Twitter to share their personal experience.One warned against getting into the habit of people contactable outside of hours saying it is a rod for your own back, adding: I don't even think about work until I step into the office.If people know you will respond out of hours then they will come to expect it.Another said that during her commute from Brighton to London she only put in the extra time because she felt it was expected.&nbspNonetheless, she claimed that she misses &ldquothat extra time to work.&nbsp

Pet turtle used as ASH-TRAY by thugs who caused burns                Butt ends that are draining our marine lifeI just think people should be more aware of their surroundings and dispose of cigarettes properly.Ms&nbspHarnaman, a nursery worker, and her daughter were on their way back from picking up Sophia's five-year-old sister Eilidh from Clovenstone Primary at around 3pm.Ms&nbspHarnaman's&nbspsister Chloe Louise Martin was also with them when they smelt smoke as they passed a bus stop on Clovenstone Road.Ms Martin, a sales assistant, said: My sister found a cigarette in the pram.A smoker's carelessly discarded cigarette landed in Sophia's pram and burnt her arm (Image: SWNS)The family has been left hoping the five-week-old has no lasting scar  (Image: SWNS)It'd burnt right through the snowsuit thankfully not quite reaching the skin.It all happened really quickly.My sister picked her up and took her out of the suit. Then Sophia started crying because the blister started and I think that's when it hurt her the most.They rushed Sophia home to douse cold water on her arm before taking her to the doctors in Sighthill and then on to the Sick Kids.                Love child of two prehistoric species of humans unearthed in cave                Shock moment selfie-taking couple IGNORE baby in pram as wave CRASHESSophia was in her pram when the incident happened (Image: SWNS)Medics treated and dressed the blister, about the size of a one penny coin, and will assess Sophia again tomorrow.Ms Martin added: You hear about things like this but you never think it's going to happen to youA post shared on Facebook warning smokers to be more careful has been shared more than 2,000 times and attracted widespread support.Ms Martin explained: We just want to raise some awareness so that smokers can perhaps take a little more care with where they put their cigarette ends so that things like this don't happen.Amy grabbed screaming Sophia and took off her smouldering coat  (Image: SWNS)Eilidh can't understand how something like this could happen. She didn't really want to go to school or leave her sister.The family have no idea whose cigarette was responsible and are convinced it was all an unfortunate accident.Ms Martin said: There were a few people there and a bus coming towards the bus stop so we think they just flung the fag end and got on the bus.I just think it's one of the last things you think about but that's why there's a bin there with an ashtray on top.We're not looking to put the blame on anyone. We just want to stress it was an accident and for people to be more careful and vigilant.

title: Brexit news Nick Timothy Theresa May Prime Minister
story: Theresa May has been told to SCRAP Chequers for &lsquoCanada plus-plus&rsquo Brexit by ex top aid Nick Timothy (Image: )Nick Timothy, who served as her chief of staff when she took office until the 2017 general election, has come out publicly against the Government&rsquos current approach to negotiations.The controversial Brexit plan agreed by Theresa May&rsquos Cabinet at Chequers, then translated into a white paper in July, provoked the resignations of Brexit Secretary David Davis and Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson.He said it was &ldquonever going to be acceptable to the EU, because it drives a coach and horses through its core principles.&nbspMr Timothy said: &ldquoThe Prime Minister always knew that her Chequers Plan &ndash problematic as it is &ndash was only an opening pitch that would not survive its first contact with the European Union negotiators.                Britain heading for 'worst' Brexit deal: Theresa May told to get TOUGH                Brexit news: Barnier makes U-turn on UK offer &ndash prepare for no dealThis was said to be because it aims to &ldquocherry pick perks including de facto membership of the single market in goods without accepting corresponding obligations, such as the free movement of people.He anticipated the EU would demand further concessions including freedom of movement and major annual payments too Brussels.However, Mr Timothy said: &ldquoThere is no reason why a trade agreement cannot be agreed if the Government rejects further EU demands for concessions.&nbsp&ldquoThe withdrawal treaty could still include a transition period, a binding commitment to a trade agreement more ambitious than the EU&rsquos treaty with Canada, and &ndash conditional upon the ratification of the trade agreement &ndash Britain&rsquos full exit payment.Boris Johnson resigned over the Chequers Plan (Image: )The Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement between Canada, the European Union is geared at virtually eliminating tariffs between Canada and the EU.Mr Timothy conceded that the Chequers agreement was intolerable to hardline Brexiteers. Writing in the Daily  he said: &ldquoBy proposing a customs policy that makes an independent trade policy unlikely, tying Britain to EU laws, and following the rulings of the European Court of Justice, Chequers erased the Government&rsquos red lines.Opposition from both the EU and members of the Conservative Party justified a change in approach.His intervention comes after Mrs May encountered more problems with Brexit negotiations today.                EU 'ided and ruled' UK into accepting WORST possible Brexit deal                Chequers deal labelled &lsquoINTOLERABLE&rsquo by Theresa May's old advisorIt emerged she will be given another chance to brief her fellow heads of state on the issue, but has been denied the possibility of holding a discussions with them about the ongoing negotiations.Austrians had made plans for the Prime Minister to be given a Brexit-only dinner for leaders to discuss talks as they enter their final crucial stages.However, a number of member states intervened and rejected the proposal in order to preserve the EU&rsquos negotiating approach, which is headed up by chief negotiator Michel Barnier.Mrs May will still be given the opportunity to update EU leaders on her plans but there will be no added room for discussions at the Salzburg summit on September 20.

story: Pensions could be lost to expats after Brexit (Image: )The Treasury gave the warning in a technical paper setting out financial implications of a deal not being agreed with the European Union over Brexit.Annuities - which people rely on for a regular pension income - are shown to be among financial products expats could struggle to claim.The document said: &ldquoIn the absence of action from the EU, EEA-based customers of UK firms currently passporting into the EEA, including UK citizens living in the European Economic Area, may lose the ability to access existing lending and deposit services, insurance contracts (such as life insurance contracts and annuities).&ldquoFor UK-based customers who access banking, insurance, investment funds and other financial services with European Economic Area firms currently passporting into the UK, temporary permissions will enable these firms to continue to provide these services to UK customers for up to three years after exit - allowing firms time to apply for authorisation to continue operating in the UK.                Brexit latest: Expat Britons could LOSE pensions if EU talks COLLAPSE                May told to SCRAP Chequers for &lsquoCanada plus-plus&rsquo Brexit dealConcern Britons living in the European Union after Brexit could see their pension payments stopped was raised by influential House of Commons Treasury committee chair Nicky Morgan MP last year.She threw her support behind industry calls for the issue to be addressed in Government Brexit talks.&nbspMs Morgan, who put the Treasury on alert in a letter to Chancellor Philip Hammond, said: &ldquoThe possibility that UK providers may not be legally able to pay out pensions or insurance contracts to citizens in the EU &ndash including UK expats &ndash is a stark example of the consequences of a &lsquocliff edge&rsquo Brexit.Hugh Savill, director of regulation at the Association of British Insurers, said: &ldquoLeaving the EU without a deal would cause major inconvenience to millions of pensioners, travellers and drivers. We urge the Government to agree a deal as a matter of urgency.Nicky Morgan warned about the impact of Brexit on expats' pensions (Image: )&ldquoObviously insurers want to meet their commitments to their customers, but this problem has the potential to affect millions of insurance customers, including UK pensioners overseas.&nbsp&ldquoIt can be fixed by co-operation between the UK and EU regulators &ndash if the EU authorities wish to do so. Insurers have of course been making contingency plans for their own operations for many months now, but this contract issue is not one that insurers themselves can fix.Brexit minister Dominic Raab played down the threat that thousands of British retirees i- many living in Spain - could lose out on pensions.He said: &ldquoIt&rsquos hardly in the interests of southern Spain to do harm to the UK pensioners out there.The Government said it was committed to enabling a &ldquogeneral transitional tool to phase in changes easing the impact if no deal is agreed.

story: Hurricane Norman forms in Pacific: The storm has rapidly intensified (Image: NOAA)As of 10am BST on Thursday morning, the storm was churning about 600 miles southwest of the southern tip of Mexico&rsquos Baja California, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) reported.The Category 3 hurricane is packing maximum sustained winds of 155mph.Norman is moving west at seven miles per hour as it heads across the Pacific.While currently it looks set to head in the general direction of Hawaii, it is too early to forecast the storm&rsquos route and potential weakening at this stage.                Hurricane Maria death toll SOARS to 2,975 from 64Currently, NOAA is expecting Norman to keep moving west throughout tonight.On Friday, a west-southwestward motion is anticipated, before the storm zigzags back to the west over the weekend.NOAA said in a public advisory: &ldquoSatellite images indicate that Norman has been intensifying rapidly.&ldquoAdditional strengthening is forecast during the next 24 hours.Hurricanes Norman and Maria: Maria on the left and Norman to the right as they churn across the sea (Image: WINDY)The massive storm is expected to begin gradually weakening by Friday night or Saturday.Currently, hurricane-force winds extend outward up to 15 miles from the centre of the storm, and tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 70 miles.Meanwhile, another massive storm is marching across the Pacific: Hurricane Maria.The NOAA reported that Tropical Storm Miriam became a Category 1 hurricane this morning as it moved into the central Pacific.                Hawaii Hurricane: Storm Lane batters Hawaii with 52 inches of rain                Hawaii weather forecast: Rain forecast for flooded Hawaiian islandsMiriam is about 1090 miles east-southeast of Hilo, Hawaii, and is moving west at 9mph.Hurricane Miriam is packing maximum sustained winds of 75mph.A turn toward the west-northwest with a decrease in&nbspforward&nbspspeed is expected tonight.Norman is expected to turn toward the northwest and north through Friday night.Hurricane Norman forms in Pacific: The latest NOAA forecast (Image: NOAA)Miriam is expected to begin weakening on Friday as it encounters strong upper-level winds and cooler waters.Some additional strengthening is possible during the next 24 hours, but Miriam is expected to begin weakening on Friday as it encounters strong upper-level winds and cooler waters.There are no coastal watches or warnings in effect for either Norman or Miriam.These latest advisories come as Hawaii is mopping up after the chaos left by Hurricane Lane.Hurricane Miriam: The latest NOAA forecast for Hurricane Miriam (Image: NOAA)The islands were hit with &ldquocatastrophic flooding, with an unconfirmed number of homes destroyed and flooded roads are still closed, authorities said.County Managing Director Will Okabe estimated the clean-up operation could run into the millions.Hawaii News Now reported Mr Okabe saying: &ldquoWe are going to have to ask for more financial assistance whether it's from the state or from the federal government.It's definitely going to be a challenge to go through the assessment process to really get a handle of the cost.

title: Bird flu news China UK pandemic
story: China risks global pandemic with new deadly bird flu strain (Image: )Countries are usually happy to share viral samples in the common interest of stopping the spread of dangerous viruses, under an agreement established by the World Health Organisation.But China has so far caused outrage by refusing to do this, despite a request reportedly made more than a year ago by top British scientists.There have been at least 1,625 cases of H7N9 in humans so far in China. About 40 per cent of those people infected have died.The UK and United States have prioritised gathering as much intelligence as possible on the virus, which England's deputy chief medical officer warned is a strong candidate for becoming the next global flu pandemic.                Bird flu discovered in China - &lsquohighly pathogenic&rsquo H5N6 found at farmBird flu in China mostly spreads through chickens (Image: )They want to study any changes in its genetic structure, to help develop a vaccine as quickly as possible.Prof Ian Jones, an expert in virology at the University of Reading, said: &ldquoIf the virus is going to jump, you want to be ahead of the game with a vaccine.China reportedly shared early forms of H7N9 in 2013 and 2016 with other countries.But a request said to have been made by the UK more than a year ago - for samples of the latest strain - was said by a source to have been ignored.                Bird flu H7N4 outbreak: Four symptoms to watch for                 Deadly bird flu RETURNS: Hundreds of birds KILLED and thousands culledChina has also snubbed approaches from the USA for over 12 months.The virus was first identified in humans in 2013, but may have been common among birds for much longer.It generally does not have a visible affect on birds, but symptoms among humans include a high fever, cough and shortness of breath.Those with the severe form of the disease develop acute respiratory distress syndrome &ndash where the lungs cannot provide the body with enough oxygen &ndash septic shock and multi-organ failure.China was said to have given no reason for its failure to share samples of the virus with other countries.

title: Mystery Jesus turning water to wine archeologists discovery israel world
story: For hundreds of years, pilgrims have believed the site of the miracle to be Kafr Kanna, a town in northern Israel, where they visit the 20th-century Wedding Church.But the true location has long been debated &ndash and now archaeologists believe the Cana of biblical times may be a dusty hillside five miles further north.It&rsquos the former site of Khirbet Qana, a Jewish village between the years of 323BC and AD 324, where archaeologists have discovered a number of compelling clues.Excavations there have revealed a network of tunnels used for Christian worship, marked with crosses and references to Kyrie Iesou, a Greek phrase meaning Lord Jesus.                Jesus Christ or not the man suffered EXTREME TORTURE says study                LIFE AFTER DEATH: Woman &lsquomeets&rsquo Jesus and God in AFTERLIFEThere was also an altar and a shelf with the remains of a stone vessel, plus room for five more.Six stone jars like this held the wine in the biblical account of the miracle.Dr Tom McCollough, who directs excavations at the site, said there were three other sites with a credible claim to being the Cana of scripture.&ldquoBut none has the ensemble of evidence that makes such a persuasive case for Khirbet Qana, he said.Archaeologists believe the Cana could be the place of the miracle  (Image: Penmedia )There was also an altar and a shelf with the remains of a stone vessel (Image: Penmedia)&ldquoWe have uncovered a large Christian veneration cave complex that was used by Christian pilgrims who came to venerate the water-to-wine miracle.&ldquoThis complex was used beginning in the late fifth or early sixth century and continued to be used by pilgrims into the 12th-century Crusader period.&ldquoThe pilgrim texts we have from this period that describe what pilgrims did and saw when they came to Cana of Galilee match very closely what we have exposed as the veneration complex.As part of his evidence, Dr McCollough points to the work of first-century Jewish historian Flavius Josephus.He said: &ldquoHis references to Cana align geographically with the location of Khirbet Qana and align logically with his movements.                Life after death: Man claims to meet JESUS in afterlife&ldquoThe reference to Cana in Josephus, the New Testament and in the rabbinic texts would argue the village was a Jewish village, near the Sea of Galilee and in the region of lower Galilee.&ldquoKhirbet Qana fulfills all of these criteria.As for the better-known site at Kafr Kanna, Dr McCollough is sceptical.&ldquoWhen tourists visiting Israel today are taken to Cana, they are taken to Kafr Kanna, he said.&ldquoHowever, this site was not recognised as a pilgrimage site for those seeking Cana until the 1700s.It&rsquos the former site of Khirbet Qana, a Jewish village between the years of 323BC and AD 324 (Image: penmedia)&ldquoAt this point the Franciscans were managing Christian pilgrimage and facilitating easy passage rather than historical accuracy.Dr McCollough believes the discoveries at Khirbet Qana could even bolster the case for the historicity of the Gospel of John.He said: &ldquoOur excavations have shown that this was in fact a thriving Jewish village located in the heart of much of Jesus&rsquos life and ministry.&ldquoFor the Gospel of John, Cana is in some ways, Jesus&rsquos safe place or operational centre. It is a place He and His disciples return to when they encounter resistance in Judea.&ldquoI would argue our excavations warrant at least a reconsideration of the historical value of John&rsquos references to Cana and Jesus.

Everything is open to him.&ldquoEveryone would be happy if Mick steps in his father's footsteps.Mick has made no secret of his ambitions to emulate his father&rsquos record-breaking exploits on the F1 scene.Mick Schumacher 'has is father's racing genes' (Image: )Mick Schumacher has made no secret of his ambitions to emulate his F1 legend father (Image: )He said: &ldquoHe was my idol. I am following everything he did to see if I can use it myself and I am really happy with that.&ldquoThe goal is to win in F1, that is the aim. My dad had a huge influence on my career.&ldquoYou still have to show what you can do. Michael Schumacher&rsquos son tipped for F1 career: 'Dad is my role model'Despite his desire to reach the top of the sport, Mick wants to keep his feet firmly on the ground and has first set his sights on being a success in Formula 3.Formula 3 has traditionally been regarded as the first major stepping stone for F1 hopefuls and is typically the first point in a driver&rsquos career at which most drivers in the series are aiming to switch from amateur to professional careers.Past champions in the racing series include several F1 champions and some of the sport&rsquos most decorated drivers, including Ayrton Senna, Jackie Stewart, Jim Clarke and Mika H&aumlkkinen.Mick said: F3 is an important step for that, and the next step has to be Formula 2, but my goal is to step up and show what I can do.Michael Schumacher, the most successful racing driver in history.                    AFPGetty Images1 of 24Michael Schumacher is pictured at the Valencia Street Circuit in 2009Mick was with his father on the slopes in the French Alps in December 2013 when the sporting legend suffered a severe brain injury after falling and hitting his head on a rock while skiing.His medical condition has been a closely guarded secret ever since but recently family members said he was capable of showing signs of emotion and sometimes cried.

title: just ignore bogus chancellor hammond the sun is brexing out
story: Of course, she was right to ask.Not a single public authority predicted the biggest crash in modern history — not the Bank of England, not the ­Treasury, and certainly not the Chancellor of the Exchequer.Then in 2016 they did it again. Project Fear forecast dramatic downturns in the economy if the people were so unwise as to vote for Brexit. Wrong again.Since then, we have had record levels of employment, huge investments from the likes of Google, Microsoft, SoftBank and a long list of other companies.They demonstrated their confidence in the future of this great country in the best way possible — with their money.This time round the wise insight came from Andy Haldane, the best economist at the Bank of England.Ruefully he said “economic forecasting is having a Michael Fish moment”.Michael Fish was the weather forecaster who completely mispredicted the huge 1987 storm that struck Britain.If only economic forecasters were even as good as weather forecasters, we would be a lot better off. But they are not, and they are at it again.This week Chancellor Philip Hammond predicted the Treasury would need to raise an extra £80billion in 15 years’ time in the event of a no-deal Brexit.And yet the Chancellor insists on ­trotting out yet another bogus forecast, on the very day that my successor as Brexit Secretary, Dominic Raab, is ­presenting the first set of preparation for no deal.Coincidence? I do not think so.The great departments of state are very careful about what they put in the public domain, and exactly when.For nobody is this more true than the Treasury, which has to judge the public perception of everything it does, if only because of its effect on the markets. So this was either spectacularly incompetent, or deliberate. I know what I think.And even more disgraceful, by doing so it will undermine the Government’s hand in striking a deal with the EU.If they do not think we dare walk away, then they will give us the worst deal they can think of. Bear in mind that the Chequers deal already concedes enormous amounts to the EU.It would not be long before our world-leading position in life sciences, gene technology, artificial intelligence, self-driving cars and a whole range of other modern industries would be being actively undermined by the Europeans.As for being out of reach of the ­European Court, pull the other one.But now the Treasury is beginning to fear that even these spectacular concessions the Government has made in the Chequers deal will not deliver agreement from the European Commission — or if it does, the Commons will turn it down.In that event you can expect attempts by the Remainers in Parliament to try to scupper our departure by delaying it beyond the General Election, or offer some other enormous raft of concessions to give back control of the EU.Hence the ridiculous suggestion that the Army would be used to move food around the country.Why? What conceivable aspect of European policy would handicap British hauliers moving British products from Kent to Cumbria?None of course, but it was just the bogus nonsense some of our Remainer media is only too happy to carry ­completely uncritically. Similarly, we have heard suggestions of all sorts of shortages, based it seems mostly on the idea that the French might impede the flow of goods between Calais and Dover.It would not be the first time we had dealt with such issues. We had about 30 days of such delays in 2015. I remember queues of lorries, but I do not remember shortages of food or medicines.And on other issues, are the Europeans really going to pick a fight on data with the biggest IT power on the continent, on banking are they going to refuse to cooperate with the greatest financial ­centre in the world?Are the Greeks, Italians and Spaniards going to disadvantage the UK residents on whom many of their local economies depend? Or stop tourism? I think not.I suspect we are quite likely to have the odd hiccup when we leave the EU, but we will be able to cope, which is what Dominic Raab was demonstrating this week. And any problems we have will be over in months not years.So in 15 years’ time, far from worrying about Mr Hammond’s £80billion bill, the country will have trouble remembering what all the fuss was about.The biggest question will be whether we have made the most of the opportunities created by Brexit.And that is what we should worry about today, creating the circumstances where this great country can take its proper place in the world. We will only be able to do that if we allow ourselves the freedoms a clean Brexit will deliver.So my advice to all my old colleagues in Cabinet is simple: Ignore the misery merchants of the Treasury, stop fearing things that will never happen, and start planning for the real opportunities that this great country can grasp when it sets its mind to it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun says theresa may trade deals africa
story: A major factor of the Leave vote was for Britain to become an independent nation, free to strike global trade deals with fast-growing, emerging economies.So the Prime Minister is absolutely right to start outlining trade policy with our Commonwealth allies South Africa, Nigeria and Kenya.She is also right to call for funds from our bloated foreign aid budget to be diverted from frivolous handouts and used instead on developing infrastructure and security in Africa.As we unshackle ourselves from Brussels, it is clear Africa presents us with huge opportunities.It is the world’s second biggest continent, home to 16 per cent of the global population. Its GDP is growing rapidly. Similar to India, its middle classes are rocketing. And its workforce is estimated to be larger than China’s by 2035.Over 17 millions Brits voted for a Brexit that would make us a freer, richer country.This is exactly the type of buccaneering move that will make that vision a reality.THE EU’s threats regarding a No Deal Brexit are total bluster.The bloc claims there will be chaos if we leave without a deal, that the impact on trade and travel will be so severe we will crawl back to the negotiating table.But behind closed doors, the EU admits this is codswallop.The EU Commission has drawn up secret No Deal plans that are “very similar” to Britain’s Brexit preparation.In other words, in the event of a No Deal they will keep things almost exactly the same because they don’t want to be hit.What a surprise.WHEN will Labour moderates realise their party is beyond repair?Jewish Labour MPs need bodyguards for the party conference next month. There is a backlog of anti-Semitism complaints that could take YEARS to probe. And their leader is an ­anti-Semitic IRA-apologist, who counts the former BNP leader and the KKK among his cheerleaders.By staying in the party, Labour MPs signal that they want Corbyn to be PM.No amount of tribal loyalty can make them think that is a good idea.IT is shocking that deadly diet pills are being brazenly flogged on Instagram.The Facebook-owned company must better protect youngsters.It should hire a proper workforce to establish oversight of what is put online.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jehovahs witnesses
story: “Olympia doesn’t celebrate birthdays,” the 36-year-old said. “We’re Jehovah’s Witnesses, we don’t do that.”While for most of us our knowledge of Jehovahs Witnesses is their frequent door-knocking to try and convert you, a surprising number of celebs - including Serenas sister Venus and model Naomi Campbell - are followers or were raised in the faith.And there are unusual rules members have to follow: they cant have life-saving blood transfusions, are unable to vote or date without chaperones being present - and are forbidden from having oral sex both in and out of marriage.Serena and sister Venus were raised as Jehovahs Witnesses by their mother Oracene Price, who converted to the religion in the 1980s.Serena has been more outspoken about the religion - which was started in the 1870s in the US - constantly thanking Jehovah God for her success as a tennis player.In a recent Vogue interview she also said: Being a Jehovah’s Witness is important to me, but I’ve never really practiced it and have been wanting to get into it.Alexis [Serenas husband] didn’t grow up going to any church, but he’s really receptive and even takes the lead. He puts my needs first.”Legendary singer Prince, who passed away in April 2016, converted to the faith in 2001 following the death of his mother.He described his conversion as: a realisation. Its like Morpheus and Neo in The Matrix.A committed Jehovahs Witness to the end, a memorial for the star took place at the Kingdom Hall of Jehovahs Witnesses near his Minnesota home to commemorate his life.Canadian model Coco Rocha has opened up about her life as a devout Jehovahs Witness saying: faith is everything and despite her fame, she still preaches door-to-door.The whole purpose is to inform people. Some people think we’re a pushy religion, but if you’re not interested, just say so, she explained to luxury magazine Dujour.Naomi Campbells mum Valerie is also a follower, telling Vogue: I brought up Naomi as a Jehovahs Witness, but she must choose her faith for herself. I do give her literature on the subject though when she asks for it.However, the model has not followed in her mothers footsteps by becoming a believer.Other A-list celebs, including Janet Jackson, Ja Rule and actress Michelle Rodriguez were raised in the faith as children, but no longer practise it.Members follow their own version of the Bible called the New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures.They say our world now belongs to Satan, and because of this God  - who they call Jehovah - will end it very soon in order to create a new kingdom.Jehovahs Witnesses are not meant to make friends with people of other faiths, as non-believers are considered to belong to Satans world - although this isnt always strict as their celebrity followers show.Many followers say there is a a sense of community that can come with being a Jehovahs Witness - as they are tight-knit and have respect for each other.The easy-to-follow belief system is also a big draw for people interested in the faith, and the organisation has a lot of literature providing what they believe to be the answers to lifes big questions.A Jehovahs Witness church: followers of the faith reject blood transfusions as they are seen as sinfulJehovahs Witnesses are barred from having blood transfusions - which makes operations like Caesarean sections - that often require them - more difficult to complete, as blood products are linked to immorality.As one Jehovahs Witness told the New Yorker: It’s as much a sin to take a blood transfusion as to have an extramarital affair.This has led to several deaths - and ious court battles between Jehovahs Witnesses and doctors seeking to treat them.Last Autumn, a 27-year-old Canadian new mother, Éloïse Dupuis, died a week after giving birth due to haemorrhaging - but despite doctors pleas for her to have a blood transfusion she refused.Jehovahs Witnesses dont believe in sex before marriage - and dating isnt condoned unless they bring along a chaperone as well.So its likely that the first person you choose to date will be the person you marry.And after marriage, theres still restrictions on sex - namely anal and oral sex which are strictly forbidden, something that is also frowned upon in religions such as Islam and other forms of Christianity.Followers are peaceful - even refusing military service - but are suffering from persecution in some countries.Earlier this year, they were declared as an extremist group in Russia with raids on their churches and several arrests - its thought hundreds have fled the country and applied for asylum in Finland since.Other things they are prohibited from doing include being patriotic, as it is seen as worshipping an idol, or voting or canvassing for political parties as they remain politically neutral.As Jesus never celebrated his birthday, Jehovahs Witnesses dont mark theirs either, and they dont acknowledge the major Christian holidays of Christmas Day or Easter, as they believe these festivals are based on pagan customs.On the plus side, it means they probably save a lot of money due to not having to fork out for expensive gifts.Their beliefs in the end of the world have led to a series of unfulfilled prophecies.In 1975 they were told the world would end and members of the church were encouraged to preach full-time and get rid of their possessions.Thousands of them quit their jobs and sold their homes - but Armageddon didnt come leading to a drop in membership, something which has remained in decline ever since.Armageddon was also promised before the start of the Millennium, but again never materialised.There has also been other controversies: the Charity Commission are currently investigating claims that some followers were abused as children by fellow members of the faith.Members are known for their recruitment drives: previously, they would go door-to-door to try and recruit new converts, handing out literature that explains their beliefs.However, people who have left the church have described this as being exhausting.One said: I barely got any sleep when I was a Witness...I needed the weekends to catch up on my sleep debt, but instead I had to get up at the crack of dawn to go out preaching.Followers of the religion are now more commonly found preaching outside train stations across the UK, and in London alone their volunteers give out an estimated 100,000 magazines every month.The publication, Awake!, has been running since 1919, and with a global circulation of 65 million they show no sign of stopping recruiting any time soon. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eus chief negotiator accused of avoiding brexit talks with dominic raab while posting pics from his holiday
story: The pound soared after Michel Barnier’s comments that Britain could end up with an unprecedentedly close relationship with Brussels after it exits the bloc in March next year.Speaking in Berlin he appeared to break months of stalemate by saying: “We are prepared to offer Britain a partnership such as there never has been with any other third country.”After holding meetings with German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas, he added that the agreement could include economic as well as foreign and security policy ties.Mr Barnier has repeatedly said the UK will not be able to cherry pick its own bespoke agreement.He has stuck to the line that we will have to follow an existing model such as the relationship Norway or Canada currently enjoy with Brussels.But todays comments mark the most significant shift in rhetoric by the EUs top brass in months, and raises hopes of a deal being hammered out this autumn.And it is a significant boost for Theresa May, who has spent the summer trying to convince leaders across the continent to accept her White Paper proposals.However he also warned: “We respect Britains red lines scrupulously. In return, they must respect what we are.Single market means single market ... There is no single market a la carte.In response to Mr Barnier’s change in stance, sterling rallied sharply against both the dollar and the euro this afternoon as the markets reacted to the decreasing chance of there being a “no deal” Brexit.His comments came just as the Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab was appearing in front of Lords Committee to answer questions about how the EU negotiations were going.He rejected suggestions from a Labour peer that Theresa May’s Chequers agreement amounted to “begging for a deal, saying: “I don’t beg.”And he said he was prepared to play hardball with Brussels over our £39billion “divorce payment”, suggesting the UK could choose to withhold some of it if a long-term agreement cannot be agreed.The Cabinet minister added: Im confident that a deal is within our sights. Were bringing ambition, pragmatism, energy and if, and I expect it will be, and if it is matched, we get a deal.There was a light-hearted moment when Lord Liddle’s mobile phone went off in the committee room and Mr Raab joked: Its probably someone from Brussels trying to check in on the money.He had been speaking about the UK’s plans for providing the EU with a the financial settlement, saying a “no-deal” scenario could affect arrangements over payments to the EU.Mr Raab said: The financial settlement, as its calibrated in the withdrawal agreement, reflects a whole range of considerations not just the strict legal obligations.“And if we left with no deal then not only would there be a question around quite what the shape of those financial obligations were as a matter of strict law, but secondly on the timing.Remember that the timing of payments is actually - we overlook it on our side - rather important on the EU side because of the way money is distributed.“But I dont think it could be safely assumed on anyones side that the financial settlement as has been agreed by the withdrawal agreement would then just be paid in precisely the same shape or speed or rate if there was no deal.As I said that would be a peculiar position for the UK to take because we view the package as a whole.It comes as Mr Barnier was accused of avoiding having more Brexit talks with Mr Raab because of diary issues - while also posting pictures from his holidayHe previously said he is available 24-7 for discussions with the Brexit Secretary – but the minister has complained his requests for discussions have been knocked back by Brussels.Earlier this month the pair vowed to speed up the drawn-out process of debating Theresa May’s Chequers plan with the autumn deadline for a deal looming.They said they would have “continuous talks” from then on, but today there are reports UK officials are “tearing their hair out” at the EU’s failure to live up to this promise.The two sides were due to spend this week locked in negotiations, but Mr Barnier only offered Mr Raab a three-hour slot this Friday because of his schedule commitments.It came after he tweeted an image of himself in the sunshine in eastern France on Sunday.The  reported that after complaints from the British side that has been extended to five hours, but it says diplomats have raised this issue several times.The newspaper reports that the EU commission’s claim, repeated by a spokesman on Tuesday, that Mr Barnier was available day or night has been proved to be false.Mr Raab hinted at his frustration when at a press conference last week he expressed hope for a longer meeting this week.And he also suggested a deal would require “energy on both sides”, as they admitted the October deadline for hammering out a deal had slipped to the end of the year.In response an EU official said: “The commission is working for a deal. Negotiation agendas, including meetings between principals, are decided jointly.“The aim of the meetings between the principals is to take stock of progress made at technical and coordinator level.”The Department for Exiting the European Union said: “Both the secretary of state and Michel Barnier are committed to weekly discussions to ensure that both sides get a good deal.”Responding to todays story Mr Raab said: I shall be over in Brussels tomorrow evening for a long, substantive meeting on Friday, I hope that gives you the facts directly with Michel Barnier.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
